In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

Here's how you can do it using the DataFrames package in Julia.
```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(x -> Dates.year(x)*100 + Dates.month(x), df[:dt])
end
```
This function takes a DataFrame as input and adds a new column `ym` to it. The values in this new column are calculated by mapping over the original column `dt`, extracting the year and month from each DateTime, and then concatenating them together. 

Note: This assumes that your DataFrame has a column named "dt" which contains DateTime objects. If you have different column names, you will need to adjust the function accordingly.
